messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 47 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Neural Population Learning beyond Symmetric Zero-sum Games

Paper Abstract: Abstract. We study computationally efficient methods for finding equilibria in n-player general-sum games, specifically ones that afford complex visuomotor skills. We show how existing methods would struggle in this setting, either computationally or in theory. We then introduce NeuPL-JPSRO, a neural population learning algorithm that benefits from transfer learning of skills and converges to a Coarse Correlated Equilibrium (CCE) of the game. We show empirical convergence in a suite of OpenSpiel games, validated rigorously by exact game solvers. We then deploy NeuPL-JPSRO to complex domains, where our approach enables adaptive coordination in a MuJoCo control domain and skill transfer in capture-the-flag. Our work shows that equilibrium convergent population learning can be implemented at scale and in generality, paving the way towards solving real-world games between heterogeneous players with mixed motives.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 47 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 47"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Maximum a Posteriori Policy Optimisation",
        "Subjectivity and correlation in randomized strategies",
        "Emergent Complexity via Multi-Agent Competition",
        "Finding any nontrivial coarse correlated equilibrium is hard",
        "Iterative solution of games by fictitious play",
        "Superhuman AI for heads-up no-limit poker: Libratus beats top professionals",
        "Deep blue",
        "Prediction, learning, and games",
        "Near-optimal no-regret learning in general games",
        "The complexity of computing a Nash equilibrium",
        "Correlation in extensive-form games: Saddle-point formulation and benchmarks",
        "Pick Your Battles: Interaction Graphs as Population-Level Objectives for Strategic Diversity",
        "Human-level performance in 3D multiplayer games with population-based reinforcement learning",
        "Adam: A Method for Stochastic Optimization",
        "A simplified two-person poker",
        "Extensive games and the problem and information",
        "OpenSpiel: A Framework for Reinforcement Learning in Games",
        "A Unified Game-Theoretic Approach to Multiagent Reinforcement Learning",
        "Scalable evaluation of multi-agent reinforcement learning with Melting Pot",
        "Simplex Neural Population Learning: Any-Mixture Bayes-Optimality in Symmetric Zero-sum Games",
        "Emergent Coordination Through Competition",
        "From motor control to team play in simulated humanoid football",
        "NeuPL: Neural Population Learning",
        "Turbocharging Solution Concepts: Solving NEs, CEs and CCEs with Neural Equilibrium Solvers",
        "Multi-Agent Training beyond Zero-Sum with Correlated Equilibrium Meta-Solvers",
        "Pipeline PSRO: A Scalable Approach for Finding Approximate Nash Equilibria in Large Games",
        "Planning in the presence of cost functions controlled by an adversary",
        "Strategically zero-sum games: the class of games whose completely mixed equilibria cannot be improved upon",
        "A Generalized Training Approach for Multiagent Learning",
        "Safe and efficient off-policy reinforcement learning",
        "Non-Cooperative Games",
        "Œ±ùõº\\alpha-rank: Multi-agent evaluation by evolution",
        "Film: Visual reasoning with a general conditioning layer",
        "Mastering the game of Stratego with model-free multiagent reinforcement learning",
        "From Poincar√© recurrence to convergence in imperfect information games: Finding equilibrium via regularization",
        "Goofspiel‚Äîthe game of pure strategy",
        "Some studies in machine learning using the game of checkers. II‚ÄîRecent progress",
        "Progress & compress: A scalable framework for continual learning",
        "Revisiting Gaussian mixture critics in off-policy reinforcement learning: a sample-based approach",
        "A general reinforcement learning algorithm that masters chess, shogi, and Go through self-play",
        "Mastering the game of go without human knowledge",
        "Iterative Empirical Game Solving via Single Policy Best Response",
        "Bayes‚Äô bluff: opponent modelling in poker",
        "A parameterized family of equilibrium profiles for three-player kuhn poker.",
        "dm_control: Software and Tasks for Continuous Control",
        "Temporal difference learning and TD-Gammon",
        "Grandmaster level in StarCraft II using multi-agent reinforcement learning"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 47 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Neural Population Learning beyond Symmetric Zero-sum Games, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
